docs.lead_paragraph: In the latest attempt to end a five-month standoff over how to pay for hospital care for the uninsured, the State Assembly approved legislation today that would cover the costs by continuing to rely on unemployment payroll taxes. The bill was approved by the Assembly on a vote of 55 to 17, with 6 abstentions, with some Democratic support. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco support the new two-year plan, but the measure still faces uncertainty in the Republican-controlled Senate.

headline.main: Trenton May Pay Health Cost Of Uninsured by Payroll Tax

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Wider Mental Health Insurance Is Now Feasible, Experts Say" (front page, May 2): In every case I know of, the person with coverage for mental illness was given far more "treatment" than the person without coverage. Often this included in-hospital care up to the maximum of the insurance policy. At this point people are routinely released. In many cases what is being "treated" is not the patient but the insurance policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "No Money-Saving Cure" (letter, May 1), by Ronald P. Klipstein: There are no cures for diabetes, heart failure, kidney failure or hypertension: only treatment, usually medicine but occasionally even more expensive surgery, dialysis or transplant. This is one reason that widening insurance coverage to stop discrimination against people with mental illness will not necessarily increase health care costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Wider Mental Care Insurance Is Now Feasible" (front page, May 2): Requiring equivalent coverage for mental and physical illness is a worthy goal supported by mental health professionals; however, the involvement of managed mental health care consultants, who charge a fee for their services, is destructive to effective psychiatric treatment.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re Frank Rich's "Over the Cuckoo's Nest" (column, May 4): Having received calls from Baltimore's Sheppard Pratt psychiatric facility myself 30 years ago -- from my grandmother -- which we greeted with silence and shame, I endorse Mr. Rich's optimism over the Domenici-Wellstone amendment to equalize insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN Lithuania, rear-end collisions happen much as they do in the rest of the world. Cars crash, bumpers crumple and tempers flare. But drivers in cars that have been hit there do not seem to suffer the long-term complaints so common in other countries: the headaches or lingering neck pains that have come to be known as chronic whiplash, or whiplash syndrome. Cars are no safer in Lithuania, and the average neck is not any stronger. The difference, a new study says, might be described as a matter of indemnity.

headline.main: In One Country, Chronic Whiplash Is Uncompensated (and Unknown)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I was surprised, perhaps naively, that the American Association of Retired Persons plans to license its name to managed-care groups and that it derives considerable income from its agreements with insurance carriers (front page, April 29).

headline.main: A.A.R.P.'s Members Can't Trust Its Advice

docs.snippet: To the Editor:         I was surprised, perhaps naively, that the American Association of Retired Persons plans to license its name to managed-care groups and that it derives considerable income from its agreements with insurance carriers (front...

docs.lead_paragraph: In its 38 years as a lobbying behemoth and service organization for the elderly, the American Association of Retired Persons has also been in the business of selling insurance. And it has been a lucrative business indeed. In 1994, money from insurance companies generated 38 percent of the A.A.R.P.'s $382 million budget: $119 million came from the licensing fees and interest income that Prudential Life Insurance Company paid to the A.A.R.P.; $25 million came from ITT Hartford on auto and homeowner policies, and $1.7 million from other insurance on mobile homes.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the late 1980's, the first renters at Worldwide Plaza, the condominium and office complex that fills the block between Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 49th and 50th Streets, figured they had the best of all worlds. Zeckendorf Realty, the building's owner, was offering low rents, individual lobbies and huge contributions to building out the space to those pioneers who would chance coming so far west. Yet the shabby neighborhood seemed ripe for gentrification.

headline.main: Commercial Property/Worldwide Plaza and Its Neighborhood;In Hell's Kitchen, Retail Is on the Front Burner

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the 1987 movie "Baby Boom," Diane Keaton played a big-city management consultant who moved to small-town Vermont, cooked up homemade baby food, then fended off corporate America's attempt to take over her thriving enterprise. In real life, things don't always work that way: Witness Ron and Arnie Koss, 45-year-old twin brothers who moved from New York State to Vermont and developed an organic baby food wholesome enough for their own children. Despite the upstart brand's growing sales, the brothers lost control of their baby to venture capitalists and a hotshot professional manager who they say didn't even return their phone calls.
